description.plain:
“Not Strong Enough” is the fourth single and sixth track on boygenius’ upcoming debut album, the record. The track was released alongside it’s music video on March 1st, 2023 without  prior announcement.

In an interview for Rolling Stone, Phoebe Bridgers said about the song’s lyrical content,

Being like, ‘I’m not strong enough to show up for you. I can’t be the partner that you want me to be.’ But also being like, ‘I’m too fucked up. I’m unknowable in some deep way!’ Self-hatred is a god complex sometimes, where you think you’re the most fucked-up person who’s ever lived. Straight up, you’re not. And it can make people behave really selfishly, and I love each of our interpretations of that concept.”

song.embed_content: Read “Not Strong Enough” by ​boygenius on Genius
song.recording_location: Shangri-La in Malibu, California with additional recording at Sound city in Van Nuys, CA
song.title: Not Strong Enough

body.plain:
“Not Strong Enough” is the fourth single and sixth track on boygenius’ upcoming debut album, the record. The track was released alongside it’s music video on March 1st, 2023 without  prior announcement.

In an interview for Rolling Stone, Phoebe Bridgers said about the song’s lyrical content,

Being like, ‘I’m not strong enough to show up for you. I can’t be the partner that you want me to be.’ But also being like, ‘I’m too fucked up. I’m unknowable in some deep way!’ Self-hatred is a god complex sometimes, where you think you’re the most fucked-up person who’s ever lived. Straight up, you’re not. And it can make people behave really selfishly, and I love each of our interpretations of that concept.”

songs.full_title: ​​boygenius - Not Strong Enough (Tradução em Português) by Genius Brasil Traduções
songs.title: ​​boygenius - Not Strong Enough (Tradução em Português)

annotations: Revelations

Potential reference to the above verse that is seemingly about religion. Revelations: “divine guidance or inspiration”

PROPOSED SUGGESTION: additionally “revelations” is the final book in the christian bible that describes the end of the world, further tying to the bridge’s religious themes
Not strong enough to be your man

During Boygenius' January 2023 interview with Rolling Stone, Phoebe revealed that this particular line was inspired by Sheryl Crow’s 1994 single “Strong Enough”.

She further elaborated:

The two wolves inside us can be self-hatred and self-aggrandizing. Being like, ‘I’m not strong enough to show up for you. I can’t be the partner that you want me to be.’ But also being like, ‘I’m too fucked up. I’m unknowable in some deep way!'

Always an angel, never a god
 Always an angel, never a god
 Always an angel, never a god
 Always an angel, never a god
 Always an angel, never a god
 Always an angel, never a god
 Always an angel, never a god
 Always an angel, never a god
 Always an angel, never a god
 Always an angel, never a god
 Always an angel, never a god
 Always an angel, never a god

This is a thematic idea of the band’s work, that women are devalued because they are women. Men get to be gods, the highest of the spiritual hierarchy, while women are consigned to lesser angelic functions, with societal connotations of needing to remain pure and chaste. This underscores the choral statement, “Not strong enough to be your man,” where feminine inferiority is called into question and then subverted with “I lied, I am, just lowering your expectations.” Being an angel represents that lower expectation of a woman as opposed to the male gods, the standard for whom is high and rewarding. (Their band name, boygenius, even lampoons this commonplace overpraising of men.)

Black hole opened in the kitchen
 Every clock’s a different
Black hole here a metaphor for the power going out. It turns the room black. It’s common that kitchen appliances need their clocks reset following a power outage.
I tried, I can’t

The words “I can’t” serve two purposes. First, it reaffirms her previous comment that she is in fact not strong enough to be their man. Second, it leads into the next line to convey that they can’t stop staring at the fan. This may also answer the question as to why they can’t take the simple action to change the clocks—they are staring at the fan and ostensibly having a panic attack.
Close my eyes and count

When having an anxiety episode, it can be grounding to return to a safe and repetitious pattern if thinking like counting. This is what the narrator is doing in their mind once they feel themselves spiraling through anxious thoughts.
Half a mind that keeps the other second guessing

This line plays with the idiom “half a mind to x, (the other to y)” . “The other” serves two purposes. First, it alludes to this idiom. Upon that idiom not making sense, it becomes clear that this whole line is just the first clause in that idiom.

The first clause (“half a mind to keep the other second guessing”), leaves you waiting to be told what the second half of the mind is doing. However, it also answers that questions that the other half of the mind is “second guessing”. This creates the sense of the mind literally and figuratively (and semantically) warring with itself, which is typically how OCD is depicted and what this verse and chorus alludes to.
Do you see us getting scraped up off the pavement?

An allusion to an intrusive thought that one may have while driving, in an otherwise picturesque moment, nearly ruining it. She has the thought of them getting in a car accident, and their dead bodies having to be scraped off the asphalt. A horrifying and welcomed thought. She is asking almost jokingly if the other person is also having this obscure, instructive thought
Singing “Boys Don’t Cry”

“Boys Don’t Cry” was released in 1979 by The Cure. It’s a relatively upbeat track with melancholic lyrics, similar to the artistic style of Boygenius.

Bridgers has previously covered another hit single by The Cure, “Friday I’m In Love”, and Dacus has expressed her love for the group in an interview with Louder Sound, mentioning that she performed another hit, “Just Like Heaven”, with her high school band.

description.plain:
“Emily, I’m Sorry” was released within the teaser for boygenius' new debut album, the record on March 31. The song is led by Phoebe Bridgers and features backing vocals by Julien Baker and Lucy Dacus.

In an upcoming interview, the band told Rolling Stone that Bridgers first sent her bandmates “Emily I’m Sorry” right after Punisher was released, asking, “Can we be a band again?”

“We were all nervous to bring it up,” Bridgers says. “We all thought that we were more excited than the other person.”

The song is most likely about Emily Bannon, a voiceover actor and vocal artist who was rumored to be involved in a polyamorous relationship with both Phoebe and producer Chris Nelson in 2018, and then in a monogamous relationship with Phoebe after they and Chris split up in 2019. Emily referenced her relationship with Phoebe in a 2020 Thanksgiving Instagram reel, stating that Phoebe has “figur[ed] in to every single polycule i’ve been in in the past 10 years.” She also appears in the “Kyoto” music video.

song.embed_content: Read “Emily I'm Sorry” by ​boygenius on Genius
song.recording_location: Shangri-La in Malibu, California with additional recording at Sound city in Van Nuys, CA
song.title: Emily I’m Sorry

body.plain:
“Emily, I’m Sorry” was released within the teaser for boygenius' new debut album, the record on March 31. The song is led by Phoebe Bridgers and features backing vocals by Julien Baker and Lucy Dacus.

In an upcoming interview, the band told Rolling Stone that Bridgers first sent her bandmates “Emily I’m Sorry” right after Punisher was released, asking, “Can we be a band again?”

“We were all nervous to bring it up,” Bridgers says. “We all thought that we were more excited than the other person.”

The song is most likely about Emily Bannon, a voiceover actor and vocal artist who was rumored to be involved in a polyamorous relationship with both Phoebe and producer Chris Nelson in 2018, and then in a monogamous relationship with Phoebe after they and Chris split up in 2019. Emily referenced her relationship with Phoebe in a 2020 Thanksgiving Instagram reel, stating that Phoebe has “figur[ed] in to every single polycule i’ve been in in the past 10 years.” She also appears in the “Kyoto” music video.

songs.full_title: ‎boygenius - Emily I’m Sorry (Tradução em Português) by Genius Brasil Traduções
songs.title: ‎boygenius - Emily I’m Sorry (Tradução em Português)

annotations:
Yet, I can feel myself becoming (I can feel)
 Someone

Phoebe feels herself becoming someone who is unlovable to anyone but Emily, who isn’t even guaranteed to love her (hence the “could”). She often lies to impress her even though she lashes out when caught, and she knows this isn’t who she is but she lies for her anyway. Anything to make Emily think she’s someone interesting.

And I can feel myself becoming (I can feel)
 Somebody I’m not, I’m not, so

Phoebe Bridgers and Emily Bannon reconnected in early 2017 and remained close friends/partners through 2021. During this period of time, Phoebe gained massive popularity from both of her albums, Stranger In The Alps and Punisher. Phoebe has frequently discussed feeling a level of alienation and disconnect from her fame, and this line is most likely a reference to her feeling as if she is losing herself to her success.
When I pointed out where the North Star is

The North Star, or Polaris, has been used throughout history for navigation purposes. This is because it moves in a very small circle above the north celestial pole, while all the other stars in the Northern Hemisphere rotate around it. Because Polaris appears stationary in the night sky, it can be used to find “true north.”

In a less literal sense, someone’s “north star” refers to their constant beacon of hope, or their personal mission statement/consistent goal in life.

Now I’m wide awake, spiraling
 And you don’t wanna talk
 Just take me back to Montréal
 I’ll get a real job, you’ll go back to school

Phoebe has realized that maybe she hasn’t been the best partner to Emily lately and she “wakes up” literally and metaphorically. This realization made her want to change but it’s too late because Emily has had enough and doesn’t want to talk.

When you’re in a relationship and you feel anxious about it inevitably going to end you do everything to cling into them and change, hence the lyric “I’ll get a real job, you’ll go back to school”. This lyric also suggests Emily was looking for a more committed relationship and settling down and she wasn’t getting this with Phoebe.

She’s asleep in the backseat
 Looking peaceful enough to me

Throughout the song, Phoebe talks about how unsure she is of herself, and seemingly the relationship with her partner, Emily. Phoebe is wrapped up in her own problems/ thoughts/ emotions, she doesn’t realize how much she is impacting Emily. To what meets Phoebe’s eye, Emily is ok, hence she’s asleep peacefully. But internally, Emily is hurt by the uncertainty, which would be the nightmare.
Emily, I’m sorry, I just (Emily, I)

This song is likely referring to Bridgers complicated 2018 polyamorous relationship with Chris Nelson and Emily Bannon.

Chris Nelson, owner of a recording studio Sound Space and his then-girlfriend Emily Bannon had a “consensual physical relationship” with Phoebe Bridgers in 2018. Nelson and Bannon eventually broke up around the fall of 2019 but Bridgers and Bannon continued their relationship together.

Soon after the break up, Bridgers posted a statement on Instagram in support of Bannon writing, “I witnessed and can personally verify much of the abuse (grooming, stealing, violence) perpetuated by Chris Nelson. This post prompted Nelson to sue Bridgers for attempting to “destroy” his reputation and defame him on social media, according to that original September 2021 lawsuit. Nelson then pressed charges on Bridgers for “false and misleading statements" and attempted to sue Bridgers for $3.8 million. Bridgers filed to strike the lawsuit and doubled down on her support of Bannon in the filing.

Eventually the $3.8 million defamation lawsuit was dismissed as Bridgers filed dismissal request which citied California’s anti-SLAPP laws — which aim to block a plaintiff from using arduous litigation to intimidate people out of their rights to exercise free speech.

But she’s wakin’ up inside a dream
 Full of screeching tires and fire

Dreams are common themes in Bridgers’ music, and are often portrayed in a negative light, such as in “Funeral” and “Georgia”, respectively:


And I have this dream where I’m screaming underwater
And all my friends are waving from the shore

He came up from the water without a sound
With my back to the shoreline I dreamt that he drowned


A car crash would be a fitting match to Phoebe’s morbid dreams, possibly reflecting the personality of both parties.
But I know what I want

This line is contraditory to Phoebe Bridgers' 2020 track, “ICU,” on which she sings:

‘Cause I don’t know what I want
Until I fuck it up
We can burn out in the freezing cold

The juxtaposition is between the literal freezing cold of Montreal’s winter and the concept of “burning out” becoming exhausted after a period of overwork or stress. This is deliberate wordplay more than an indication of confusion.

The juxtaposition ties into the song’s overarching theme of self blame and contradicting your own thoughts and truth. The collective noun of ‘We’ hints to the idea of ‘going down together’ as the singer struggles to let go of the relationship.
She called me a fuckin’ liar

This line may be a reference to the outro of Phoebe Bridgers' “Kyoto,” which, like “Emily, I’m Sorry,” explores the narrator’s uncertainty and emotional contradictions:

Guess I lied
I’m a liar
Who lies
‘Cause I’m a liar

Bridgers also sung about being a liar, referencing her emotional shortcomings, in “Savior Complex”:

I’m a bad liar with a savior complex

description.plain: “True Blue” explores themes similar to Lucy Dacus’ third studio album Home Video, relating to ideas of moving away from home, finding oneself, trust, and unconditional love. The phrase “true blue” itself means to be “unwavering in one’s commitment; extremely loyal.”

song.embed_content: Read “True Blue” by ​boygenius on Genius
song.recording_location: Shangri-La in Malibu, California with additional recording at Sound city in Van Nuys, CA
song.title: True Blue

body.plain: “True Blue” explores themes similar to Lucy Dacus’ third studio album Home Video, relating to ideas of moving away from home, finding oneself, trust, and unconditional love. The phrase “true blue” itself means to be “unwavering in one’s commitment; extremely loyal.”

songs.full_title: ‎boygenius - True Blue (Tradução em Português) by Genius Brasil Traduções
songs.title: ‎boygenius - True Blue (Tradução em Português)

annotations:
Water freezin’ in your eyes
 You were happy and I wasn’t surprised

Freezing water implies cold, which ties into the theme of hot/cold imagery used to describe this person throughout the song.
This person is likely crying, as they have water in their eyes, but they’re happy; similar to the conflicting hot and cold imagery, this is another contradiction used to describe Dacus’s lover.
And it feels good to be known so well

Could be a reference to Lucy Dacus' “Brando”.

All I need for you to admit is that you never knew me like you thought you did

When you don’t know who you are
 You fuck around and find out

This could be an answer to Pheobe Bridgers in the previous song “Emily I’m Sorry”.

“I’m twenty-seven and I don’t know who I am (Don’t know who I am)”

Who won the fight? I don’t know
 We’re not keeping score

In healthy, trusting relationships, people fight without worrying about “one upping” the other, or keeping score. What is said is not going to be thrown back in their face later, and because of that, you can feel safe. The fact that Lucy and this person don’t even know who won the fight means that they are not prioritizing themselves, but the relationship between them.

You were born in July ’95
 In a deadly heat

Written by Dacus, these summer-timestamped lyrics echo earlier writing on the song “VB"S from her third album Home Video, released in 2021.

In the summer of ‘07, I was sure I’d go to Heaven
But I was hedging my bets at VBS

Warm imagery is also used in “Cartwheel”, and is a staple of Home Video:

Heat wave by midday
Heat lightning on a summer night

Dacus herself was born in the summer of 1995, although in May, not July.

description.plain:
boygenius return with their first song since their 2018 self-titled EP. Julien Baker takes the reins in “$20”, initially written outside of the group.

With soft punky vibes and scattered harmonies, Baker leads, with bandmates Phoebe Bridgers and Lucy Dacus finishing her sentences. As the song ends, overlapping vocals create a chaotic soundscape before Bridgers screams her heart out.

“$20” may be inspired by  another Baker-penned boygenius song, in which she sings,

Dreamcatcher on the rearview mirror
Hasn’t caught a thing yet
Twenty dollars and a souvenir
Anything’s worth trying

song.embed_content: Read “$20” by ​boygenius on Genius
song.recording_location: Shangri-La in Malibu, California with additional recording at Sound city in Van Nuys, CA

body.plain:
boygenius return with their first song since their 2018 self-titled EP. Julien Baker takes the reins in “$20”, initially written outside of the group.

With soft punky vibes and scattered harmonies, Baker leads, with bandmates Phoebe Bridgers and Lucy Dacus finishing her sentences. As the song ends, overlapping vocals create a chaotic soundscape before Bridgers screams her heart out.

“$20” may be inspired by  another Baker-penned boygenius song, in which she sings,

Dreamcatcher on the rearview mirror
Hasn’t caught a thing yet
Twenty dollars and a souvenir
Anything’s worth trying

songs.full_title: ‎boygenius - $20 (Tradução em Português) by Genius Brasil Traduções
songs.title: ‎boygenius - $20 (Tradução em Português)

annotations:
It’s a bad idea and I’m all about it
 Give it one more chance and
 Then I finally had it

This verse parallels the chorus of Julien Bakers’s Crying Wolf:

‘Cause I’m not crying wolf
I’m out here looking for them
In the morning when I wake up
Naked in their den
I swear off all the things I thought that got me here…

Both fragments are about engaging with self destructive impulses, and justifying it by asserting that this will finally be the last time.
It’s an all-night drive from your house to Reno

Reno is a city in Nevada. One of its most famous landmarks is the National Automobile Museum, where there are Ford Thunderbirds, as referenced in the next line. See them listed in their inventory here.

Pushing the flowers that come up
 Into the front of a shotgun
 So many hills to die on

In a January 2023 interview with Rolling Stone, Baker described meaning behind the song:

[The track is about the] wanting-to-poke-the-bear impulse that I’m trying to mitigate; [it’s also a meditation on Bernie Boston’s famous Vietnam protest photograph “Flower Power.”] It started to remind me of the tension between unrest and discontent with your life individually and the world writ large as a child […] I had those conversations a lot as a child, just listening to Green Day and being like, ‘Screw George Bush! War is bad! No blood for oil!’ And my parents were like, ‘You’re literally 10.’ 

“Flower Power” is the title of a photograph by American photographer Bernie Boston for the now-defunct newspaper The Washington Evening Star. Taken on October 21, 1967, during the March on the Pentagon by the National Mobilization Committee to End the War in Vietnam, the photo shows protester George Harris placing a carnation into the barrel of an M14 rifle held by a soldier of the 503rd Military Police Battalion (Airborne).



The photograph was nominated for the 1967 Pulitzer Prize.
(May I please have twenty dollars?)

“Twenty dollars” could be a reference to a line from the group’s song “Souvenir”, off their 2018 self-titled EP:

Twenty dollars and a souvenir
Anything’s worth trying

Bridgers' screaming on the outro of this track is reminiscent of the outro of “I Know The End”, the final track from her sophomore album, Punisher. Dacus and Baker provided backing vocals for the outro, as well as on several other songs on the record.

Bridgers' lines here are also reminiscent of the end of the song “100 Dollars” by rock band Manchester Orchestra, which Baker has both covered and performed live with the band:

And that’s why I am fine, I am fine, I am fine, I am fine
I just need 100 dollars
I am fine, I am fine, I am fine, I am fine
I just need 100 dollars
From you and you and you and you and you

Run out of gas, out of time, out of money
 You’re doing what you can, just makin’ it run

This could be talking about a real car or motorcycle that someone is trying to make it run, but it’s likely a metaphor for themselves; boygenius are out of time, money and energy for themselves but they’re doing what they can to stay alive – “makin’ it run”.

Baker, Dacus and Bridgers all have common themes in their own songs and their boygenius songs on the theme of mental health and depression – Souvenir has themes of self-hatred and trying everything to help, similar to this.

To the T-bird graveyard where we play with fire
 In another life, we were arsonists
 How long’s the Chevy been on cinder blocks?

“T-bird” is a colloquial name for the Ford Thunderbird, a luxury convertible car. The model of this Ford car has been discontinued, after its first mass production in 1954.

A “Chevy” or Chevrolet is an American car brand that was also making waves in the 1950s and 1960s. Although Chevrolet still manufactures cars as of 2023, many of its most iconic models such as the Camaro and Corvette are now 70+ years old.

Whilst cinder blocks are hollow concrete bricks, cinders (similar to ashes) are pieces of partly burnt material, keeping with the fiery theme of the verse.

In a 2021 interview with The Guardian, Julien talked about her forms of rebellion as a child, including some arson:

Where I grew up in the Memphis suburbs was not the epitome of cool, so I didn’t know what else to be except a goth kid. […] I would just get home from school and walk around the neighborhood, finding other kids outside. We’d go behind the storm drain and smoke cigarettes, hide from our parents and set stuff on fire. It was Tennessee! There wasn’t a lot to do.

description.plain: “Me & My Dog” is the second song on the boygenius EP. Phoebe Bridgers wrote this song about having a panic attack and wanting to escape the reality of her anxiety, and be with her dog Max, who sadly passed away.

song.embed_content: Read “Me & My Dog” by ​boygenius on Genius
song.title: Me & My Dog

body.plain: “Me & My Dog” is the second song on the boygenius EP. Phoebe Bridgers wrote this song about having a panic attack and wanting to escape the reality of her anxiety, and be with her dog Max, who sadly passed away.

annotations: I cried at your show with the teenagers

this line illustrates a complete change in their relationship. in the first verse, phoebe reminisces on what it was like when they were together but now she has resorted to watching them from the sideline. this is someone that she used to know well but now she finds herself in the same position as their teenage fans who don’t know them personally.

I never said I’d be all right
 Just thought I could hold myself together
 When I couldn’t breathe, I went outside
 Don’t know why I thought it’d be any better
 I’m fine now, it doesn’t matter

Phoebe has stated that this song is about experiencing a panic attack. These can happen at any given moment for no particular reason, there is no way to control them.
She goes outside in search of fresh air because she can’t breathe (a common symptom of panic attacks), but this is episode is psychological, so this does not make a difference.

But sometimes I still do
 Something embarrassing

This is in reference to the previous line, which was a play on words. In this line, it’s continuing with the word “cool” meaning interesting or popular, and not cold. So essentially, the writer’s partner makes them “cool” but they still occasionally do “uncool” things

I dream about it
 And I wake up falling

The sensation of falling out a dream is very common, and is known as a “hypnic jerk.” The sensation is produced when the body is transitioning between light sleep and waking up, a state known as the hypnagogic state. The sensation of falling out a dream tends to be experienced more often during particularly stressful times in a person’s life.

We had a great day
 Even though we forgot to eat
 And you had a bad dream
 And we got no sleep
 ’Cause we were kissing

Though Phoebe starts the song by saying that the day she and her partner spent together was great, she proceeds to describe things that might spoil a day: being hungry, under-rested, and having an upsetting dream. Despite all of these negative things, just spending time with her lover made her day great. The last line drives this home: the kissing that kept her awake was good enough to redeem the fatigue.
I wanna be emaciated

Compare with line two: “we forgot to eat.”
The speaker wants to return to a previous state, where she was so happy with her partner that she would forget to eat. But now she wants to be “emaciated.” It’s as though she wants to go back so badly that she’s willing to hurt herself.
https://twitter.com/phoebe_bridgers/status/1326376214416650240

I wish I was on a spaceship
 Just me and my dog and an impossible view

The narrator craves a form of escapism away from human life. Throughout the song, she details potentially unhealthy feelings brought about by the person she was in a relationship with. At this point, she wishes to rid herself of everything and just sit peacefully with her dog, in a place that provides a perspective on life like no place on Earth could.

This lyric is similar in concept to Radiohead’s “Subterranean Homesick Alien”, which in and of itself was inspired by the larger concept of Martian Poetry.

Given the group’s roots in folk music, this line could also reference Johnny Cash’s verse from “Highwayman”:

I fly a starship across the universe divide”

I had a fever
 Until I met you
 Now you make me cool

Bridgers uses a play on words with the word “cool.” A fever occurs when the body’s temperature temporarily increases in response to an illness.

Bridgers is likely using the cooling of a fever as a metaphor for her life to describe how meeting her partner made her better.

“Cool” is also a common slang term used to mean fashionable or hip. While Bridgers had previously dated singer/songwriter/abuser Ryan Adams who helped record her debut record Killer, it is possible she is referring to him in these lines — how he not only helped her breakthrough into the industry, but also put her in the limelight while the two were dating.

search_results.title: Souvenir
search_results.lyrics:
Souvenir Lyrics[Verse 1: Julien Baker]
Dreamcatcher on the rearview mirror
Hasn't caught a thing yet
Twenty dollars and a souvenir
Anything's worth trying

[Verse 2: Julien Baker]
To stay out of your nightmares
See, I was in your dream last night
Always end up dying
You said, because of course I did
[Chorus: Julien Baker]
Ooh
Ooh

[Verse 2: Phoebe Bridgers]
Always managed to move in
Right next to cemeteries
And never far from a hospital
I don't know what that tells you about me

[Verse 3: Lucy Dacus & Phoebe Bridgers, Lucy Dacus]
Pulling thorns out of my palm
Work a midnight surgery
When you cut a hole into my skull
Do you hate what you see like I do?

[Chorus: All]
Ooh
Ooh
Ooh
Ooh
Ooh
OohYou might also like11Embed

song.embed_content: Read “Souvenir” by ​boygenius on Genius
song.title: Souvenir

annotations:
Twenty dollars and a souvenir
 Anything’s worth trying

Expressing love through the purchase of material goods can sometimes be used as a stand-in for a variety of emotions. Have you ever been on a trip and found something that instantly makes you think of someone in you life that you have a complicated relationship with, so you purchase it? Or maybe you’ve been on a trip and needed to purchase an item for someone so they feel loved but you don’t find anything meaningful and you buy them a random trinket? Either way, the situation is emotionally fraught and difficult to navigate.

In this song’s context, I find it more likely that a variation of the second proposed options is true. “Souvenir”’s first verse, by Julien Baker, appears to be about being away from someone who is obligatory in your life and buying them a souvenir to placate their worry. When someone struggles with personal afflictions like substance abuse, addiction, suicidality, depression, or trauma, it can leave those surrounding that person with an ever-present sense of worry. A token knick-knack may be seen as a compromise showing progress to the worried party, making them express less outward concern or doubt. The last 2 stanza’s (“Always end up dying/ You said because of course I did”) are demonstrative of this sentiment because they imply that the possibly transactional nature of buying a souvenir to prove well-being can be a defense mechanism against legitimate concern.

Having poor mental health and being close to others can be hard because it can inspire guilt, especially when mistakes are made. Julien’s verse attempts to illustrate these difficulties and the ensuing guilt.

Dreamcatcher on the rearview mirror
 Hasn’t caught a thing yet

Dreamcatchers are traditionally used to catch nightmares, so by saying that her dreamcatcher hasn’t caught anything, she may be saying that she is still having nightmares or that she hasn’t been having nightmares so there’s nothing for it to catch.
Dream catchers are meant to catch bad dreams in their web and let good dreams through the hole in the middle. Baker states in the third and fourth lines that the souvenir dream catcher was twenty dollars, which is a steep price, but that “anything’s worth trying” to kick the bad dreams she’s been experiencing.

When you cut a hole into my skull
 Do you hate what you see like I do?

The surgeon exposes the speakers brain, which represents who a person is, their thoughts and memories.

The speaker asks if this “other” hates the speaker as much as the speaker hates themselves.
However, it could also be interpreted another way.  What they could be looking at is the depression itself. An ugly thing, that the speaker wishes was not there. Of course, the speaker could also be identifying with the disease and hates that is so much a part of their identity.
Pulling thorns out of my palm

A “thorn in the side” means something that consistently causes problems for a person. When a thorn is pulled out it can cause more pain, but briefly.

This line may be speaking about the difficult process of resolving one’s own internal issues.

Always managed to move in
 Right next to cemeteries
 And never far from a hospital
 I don’t know what that tells you about me

Although Phoebe states that she’s unsure why she always ends up moving in next to cemeteries and hospitals, her implication could be that she fixates on the morbid, or that her head is often in a dark place.

There is an implication that Phoebe (or Julien or Lucy) is always in danger of dying or being seriously hurt, and her subconscious puts her where there’s minimum effort. One can presume that this is an allusion to suicide or self harm. On top of that, the mention of a graveyard next door, where dead people are buried, before a hospital further away, where injured people are healed, implies that death is a much more attractive and relevant reality than somehow surviving through an incident.
The last line I gives the vibe that the whole verse is a “get to know me” intro paragraph on a dating website, and that subtle humour just adds layers to an already clever verse.

Phoebe also mentions living by hospitals on her song “Halloween”:

I hate living by the hospital
The sirens go all night
I used to joke that if they woke you up
Somebody better be dying

description.plain:
“Bite The Hand” is the opening track of boygenius' self-titled debut EP. While Lucy Dacus takes the lead, Phoebe Bridgers and Julien Baker provide backing vocals.

In 2019, the band received matching tooth tattoos on their wrists in memory of the song and EP. These later formed the cover of their debut album, the record (2023).

song.title: Bite the Hand

body.plain:
“Bite The Hand” is the opening track of boygenius' self-titled debut EP. While Lucy Dacus takes the lead, Phoebe Bridgers and Julien Baker provide backing vocals.

In 2019, the band received matching tooth tattoos on their wrists in memory of the song and EP. These later formed the cover of their debut album, the record (2023).

annotations:
I can’t love you how you want me to
 I can’t love you how you want me to
 I can’t love you how you want me to
 I can’t love you how you want me to
 I can’t love you how you want me to
 I can’t love you how you want me to
 I can’t love you how you want me to
 I can’t love you how you want me to
 I can’t love you how you want me to

Its not an explicit reference, but these lines share similarities with a song from Julien Baker’s solo work, a song called “Appointments” in which, there is lyric that says “I know that I’m not what you wanted, am I? Wanted someone who I used to be like”
Throughout the record, you can hear and read some subtle references to solo work from the three

I can’t love you how you want me to
 I can’t love you how you want me to
 I can’t love you how you want me to

Its not an explicit reference, but these lines share similarities with a song from Julien Baker’s solo work, a song called “Appointments” in which, there is lyric that says “I know that I’m not what you wanted, am I? Wanted someone who I used to be like”
Throughout the record, you can hear and read some subtle references to solo work from the three
Your hands are grabbing while my hands are tied

The overall theme of the song is a skewed power dynamic. This line just goes along with that dynamic, where the writer is stuck, and the subject of the line is “grabbing” which is likely just a way of saying that the subject of the line is entitled

Who do you think you are?
 Who do you think I am?
 What do you want to say?
 What do you think will change?
 Maybe I’m afraid of you
 Maybe I’m afraid of you

The bridge sounds a lot like two lovers quarreling, with one asking a vague question and the other replying in the same vague way. The argument is settled when they realize they’re both afraid of each other, and their relationship is ultimately crumbling. In reality, this is an argument between fans and an artist.

Here’s the best part, distilled for you
 But you want what I can’t give to you

In an interview with the Tampa Bay Times, Lucy spoke about how the song is essentially about the band’s relationship with their fans saying

[D]on’t feel beholden to the people that buy concert tickets. You still have to make art that’s true to yourself. Don’t be a people pleaser. Don’t feel compelled to come out after the show, because people are widely disrespectful. Even with kindness, people ask for more than anybody should give — to go out to dinner, or to kiss you on the cheek, or have a five-minute photo session or a one-on-one therapy session. It can be extremely taxing on the road, and I think all three of us need to remember that it’s okay to say no to the people that are funding your art.

In these lyrics, she sings that the version of herself she presents to her fans is not her whole self, and they should not expect more then what she is willing to give.

I’ll bite the hand that feeds me
 Bite the hand that feeds me
 Bite the hand
 Bite the hand
 Bite the hand that needs me
 Bite the hand that needs me
 Bite the hand
 Bite the hand

“Bite the hands that feeds you” is an English idiom that means criticizing or hurting those you depend on, or essentially being ungrateful to a benefactor. In this case, it references the artist’s need to maintain their own privacy and autonomous life, separate from the life and artistry they present to fans.

I can’t hear you, you’re too far away
 I can’t see you, the light is in my face
 I can’t touch you, I wouldn’t if I could

These statements are relatively literal, given from the point of view of Dacus, performing from the stage. She details lights in her eyes, amplifiers blaring, and a physical separation that exists simply because of logistics but also out of necessity for the artist’s personal space.

I can’t love you how you want me to
 I can’t love you how you want me to
 I can’t love you how you want me to

In an interview will Billboard, Julien Baker explained the line is:

…a concise way to express such a complex emotion of loving a person and also having to understand that you can love a person and you can’t all of a sudden become what they need and sacrifice your entire identity and autonomy to become some other thing.

song.embed_content: Read “Salt in the Wound” by ​boygenius on Genius
song.title: Salt in the Wound

annotations:
They say the hearts and minds are on your side
 They say the finish line is in your sights
 What they don’t say is what’s on the other side

These lines refer to some piece of advice people tend to give someone when they’re going through a hard time : trust your instincts and better days are coming. However, the artists are doubtful. You know what you leave behind but you never know what’s ahead of you.
If this is a prison, I’m willing to burn my own chain

This line is a fantastic example of Stockholm Syndrome, a psychological disorder in which victims become attached to their abuser, and don’t want to leave them, even though the abuser is hurting them.
And a kiss on my cheek

There is lots of religious imagery on boygenius, so it can be inferred that this is in reference to when Judas (one of the original 12 disciples) turns in Jesus to the Pharisees and the Roman soldiers. This leads to Jesus being betrayed with a kiss on his cheek from Judas.

TL;DR: metaphor for betrayal

Neck full of mockingbirds
 All calling your name
 I tried to sing it all back
 Like I heard it, it don’t sound the same

Mockingbirds are known for imitating melodies they hear.

The speaker trying and failing to replicate memories they have of someone. Those very memories, mere imitations of their time together, stop them from doing so – the same way a neck full of mockingbirds would stop you from singing.

You add insult to injury
 You say you believe in me
 But you haven’t decided
 About taking or leaving me
This idioms Dacus chooses create an image of a lover deciding whether or not to eat her, having two intentions just like the words here have two meanings.

You butter me up
 And you sit down to eat

Buttering someone up is a well known metaphor for ‘softening the blow.’ Following that by saying ‘and you sit down to eat’ correlates with the food theme the artist is following, and the ideology that someone is first ‘softening the blow’ before sharing their news that will have a significantly negative impact on the person they’re conferring with, hence the buttering up to make it easier for them to process.

But you take and you take
 Like silks up my sleeve
 Tied corner to corner, never ending
 Trick after trick, I make the magic
 And you unrelentingly ask for the secret

The central image of the song is that of the magician, endlessly pulling handkerchiefs out of her hand. She is contrasted against the voracious spectator, who mercilessly, again and again, works to investigate and demystify (and thereby destroy) the magic.

Laura Mulvey, (most well-known for the concept of the ‘male gaze’) writes that masculine spectators rob female characters of the power they hold by just this kind of demystification and consumption. Hence, “you take and you take”, and “you unrelentingly ask for the secret”.

TLDR; boygenius are pointing out that some secrets ought to stay secret.
You put salt in the wound

To put salt in a wound is to make an injury, physical or emotional, feel worse. The most literal meaning derived from the stinging sensation felt from the deliberate rubbing of salt in an open wound.
In a lyrical sense, Dacus feels that this person is adding to already existing pain, most likely caused by them.

I’m gnashing my teeth
 Like a child of Cain

“Gnashing of teeth” is a phrase from the The Bible often used in the context of describing hell:

They will throw them into the blazing furnace, where there will be weeping and gnashing of teeth.

-Matthew 13:42 NIV

Cain is the firstborn son of Adam & Eve, most notably famous for killing his brother Abel, as chronicled in Genesis 4 of The Hebrew Bible, or Old Testatament. As punishment, God cursed Cain to a life of wandering, before settling to build a city where he bore his son, Enoch. In the extra-biblical Book of Enoch, it describes the soul of Abel as “chief of martyrs, crying for vengeance, for the destruction of the seed of Cain.” Cain’s lineage would later end after five generations. Baker is likely comparing her suffering to that of Cain’s family, cursed by God.

description.plain:
“Ketchum, ID” is an acoustic indie-folk ballad about being in one’s 20s and longing for home while being out on the road. The song’s title is a reference to the town of Ketchum, in Idaho.

Finalized in the the studio in under an hour, Baker, Bridgers and Dacus recorded the vocals on a single microphone. With Bridgers' acoustic guitar as the only instrumental backing on the song, the trio created a beautiful and haunting piece that reminisces on isolation.

song.embed_content: Read “Ketchum, ID” by ​boygenius on Genius
song.title: Ketchum, ID

body.plain:
“Ketchum, ID” is an acoustic indie-folk ballad about being in one’s 20s and longing for home while being out on the road. The song’s title is a reference to the town of Ketchum, in Idaho.

Finalized in the the studio in under an hour, Baker, Bridgers and Dacus recorded the vocals on a single microphone. With Bridgers' acoustic guitar as the only instrumental backing on the song, the trio created a beautiful and haunting piece that reminisces on isolation.

annotations:
Everyone’s around
 And I hear you smiling

Often over the phone, you can tell when a person is smiling because of a change in their voice, which becomes higher pitched or filled with laughter. This exchange between the writer and the subject of the song happened over the phone. “Everyone’s around” is likely meant in the sense that the writer’s friends and loved ones are all around the phone, and the writer is on tour, far away from their loved ones.

Back in the States now
 In a college town

Cities that are primarily known as the home of a college or university are often called “college towns.” It’s possible that this line is about Boise, ID. Boise is home to Boise State University, and is fairly close to Ketchum, the city referenced in the song title.

Being in love
 Is the same thing as being alone
 Giving the sorrow some company
 Nothing to say
 But stay on the phone

Baker has an affinity for being “intentional about how the songs [are] structured — both lyrically and musically.” (The Daily Tar Heel, 2017) Ketchum, ID puts life through the lens of being a touring artist, and on tour, having a lover at home is essentially the same as having no lover at all.

(https://www.dailytarheel.com/article/2017/10/q-a-with-singer-songwriter-julien-baker)

Mesmerized by double lines
 Two yellow tightropes

All three of the women have talked about touring abroad extensively and the toll it takes on them. Traveling across highways is an American construct, and here Phoebe compares it to the stress of walking on a tightrope.

You say, “How are you?”
 I say, ”I don’t know

The relationship between these two people talking was once clearly close, however now they ask her how she is and she has no other response,  because it’s easier to say “I don’t know” instead of expressing the reality of  the situation and being vulnerable.

This line mimics the earlier lines “nothing to say, stay on the phone/I’m sorry I do not know what else you want from me” that express the experience of feeling obligated to engage with someone that you don’t feel close with any longer. It’s that feeling of being in a conversation that has no purpose because you don’t have anything better to say than “I don’t know.”

You say, “I love you”
 I say, “You too”

“You too” is something people say when they don’t feel comfortable saying “I love you too.”

Lucy doesn’t reciprocate the feelings that the person on the other end of the phone has, or at least she doesn’t at this current moment.

Like earlier lyrics in this song, this line is touching on the idea of losing connection and closeness from people you were once close with. It’s not that Lucy doesn’t feel comfortable saying “I love you,” but that there has been so much distance put between her and the other person that she feels like they don’t know each other anymore, they aren’t close, however, saying “you too” placates the other person’s feelings.

I am never anywhere
 Anywhere I go
 When I’m home, I’m never there
 Long enough to know

The chorus features paradoxical statements in two instances. In the first instance, the phrases “I am never anywhere,” followed by “anywhere I go” is self-contradictory. In the second instance, the phrase “When I’m home I’m never there” is yet another self-contradictory statement.

The ladies of boygenius with their sad and beautiful harmonies could likely be expressing their experiences of feeling stuck in one place, such as a tour bus, while longing to be someplace else, presumably back home. Conversely, once the group members make it back home after touring for a while, they spend such a short time at home before leaving for tour again, not having adequate time to properly feel at home.

In an interview with Pitchfork, Lucy Dacus explained the meaning behind the chorus:

[…] then we brought in the chorus about never really being anywhere when you’re on tour because you don’t ever get to see any of the places that you go. That’s the feeling all of us feel, which made it easy for each of us to write each of our own verses about distance and the strain of being on tour.

Let’s dissolve the band
 Move to Idaho”

During the group’s interview with Pitchfork, Phoebe Bridgers recalled how she first heard the the guitar lick for the song on a tour bus while traveling through Idaho, admiring the scenery. It was at that point she fantasized about leaving the tour to start a life in Idaho, a dream in which fellow group members Julien Baker and Lucy Dacus would come to share as well. Dacus elaborated on the reasons why Idaho would be the ideal place to runaway to:

It’s the most beautiful state, but everyone there just doesn’t want the rest of the world to know. I have heard from people who live there, like, ‘Be quiet please, don’t blow Idaho’s cover.’

The song was pre-released before the group’s debut EP release.

annotations:
So I stay down
 So I stay down
 So I stay down
 So I stay down
 So I stay down
“Staying down” is a form of resignation, basically like giving up and letting themself be “held underwater” as referenced earlier in the song.

It takes so long for me to settle down
 And when I finally do, there’s no one else around

A lot of people, especially introverted people or those with mental health issues, are often slow to open up and need time to get comfortable around people and are hesitant to commit emotionally. But often times the connection they are forming is deeper and more longlasting (like settling down). However, many people view this initial hesitation as rejection or a lack of interest so they turn away from the person who end up struggling to form relationships and feel loneliness.
Constantly repenting for a difficult mind?

People with anxiety and depression often struggle with difficult thoughts and unrealistic beliefs about the world/people around them. When they assume the worse of others around them or are difficult to be around because of their symptoms this puts a strain on the relationship. The narrator may be referencing the constant apologizing that she does to the other person in the relationship about her symptoms. She can also be using the term “repent” since she is made to feel bad for her mental struggles, like they are something she should seek forgiveness for from the other person.

So would you teach me I’m the villain, aren’t I?
 Aren’t I the one

This could be an example of gaslighting or perhaps the speaker repenting for things she feels she’s done wrong. When she compares herself to Jesus, she sees that he’s perfect and that she falls short.
I look at you and you look at a screen

A beautiful line that explains a far too common experience we share when with someone else in today’s world.

The narrator is trying to have a moment with another human being right in front of her, and the other human is too distracted by a screen. This person’s actions give off the vibe that the screen is more important than the person they are physically with.

This isolating moment segues beautifully into the next few lines, where the narrator explains how this makes her feel, among other things.

I’m in the back seat of my body
 I’m just steering my life in a video game -

A metaphorical description of a dissasociative disorder, often linked to depression and anxiety.
Sufferers of the condition will often feel like they are not in control of their body, and they space out or disconnect from the real world whilst continuing in every day tasks.
Baker describes this feeling through metaphor, of being a passenger in the car of her self, rather than being the driver, the one in control. She connects that to being outside of reality by feeling like life is more like a video game to her in this state, and that she is outside of that world.

Push me down into the water like a sinner, hold me under
 And I’ll never come up again

Possibly a reference to baptism, which is a metaphorical ritual Christians often undergo to demonstrate their commitment to their faith.

The ritual can represent how Jesus washes our sins. However, it is also a metaphor for Christ’s death and resurrection: the descent is meant to represent death and the ascent new life. By saying she’ll never come up again, Baker could be trying to represent a sort of spiritual death–permanent separation from God, forever surrounded by her sins in the dirty water.

This entire verse also echoes the ending of the popular video game Bioshock: Infinite.

SPOILER ALERT

At the end of Bioshock: Infinite, the hero of the game learns that he is also the villain of the game, as he has been fighting a version of himself from an alternate timeline, and in order to save the world, he allows himself to be drowned in a Baptism-like ceremony. This carries the video game theme into the bridge, where there are even more direct video game references.
There you were, turning your cheek

This could be a reference to the passage Matthew 5:38-40, commonly titled “Eye for eye”.

38 “You have heard that it was said, ‘Eye for eye, and tooth for tooth.’ 39 But I tell you, do not resist an evil person. If anyone slaps you on the right cheek, turn to them the other cheek also. 40 And if anyone wants to sue you and take your shirt, hand over your coat as well."

Baker grew up in the church, and has previously written music about anger towards God. The whole song reads like Baker is fighting with God and begging him to beat her up, yet he turns the other cheek.
It’s a half life, it’s a fallout

Half-Life and Fallout are video game series – this is a throwback to the line in the second verse.

In the second verse, she also says that she’s in the “backseat of her body”, which suggests that she’s not really living her life as herself. This suggests that when she says “it’s a half-life”, she’s referring to the life that she’s not really living.

Half life and fallout are also terms corresponding to radioactivity. In this sense, Julien could be describing herself as something dangerous that ought to be avoided.
